name: Hveradalir
description:
Hveradalir, meaning 'Hot Spring Valley,' is a spectacular geothermal area located in the heart of the Kerlingarfjöll mountain range in the Icelandic Highlands. This remote and stunningly beautiful area features an extensive field of hot springs, fumaroles, mud pots, and steaming vents set against a backdrop of colorful rhyolite mountains. The geothermal features create ribbons of bright orange, yellow, and green mineral deposits that snake through the valley, contrasting dramatically with the red and yellow volcanic rock of the surrounding peaks. The area represents one of Iceland's most concentrated and visually spectacular geothermal zones.

The valley's geothermal activity has shaped a unique landscape where boiling springs bubble alongside snowfields and glaciers, even in summer. Boardwalks and marked trails allow visitors to safely explore the active geothermal field without damaging the delicate formations or risking injury from the scalding water. The steam rising from countless vents creates an ethereal atmosphere, especially in cool weather when the vapor plumes are most visible. Hikers can observe the full spectrum of geothermal phenomena within a compact area, making Hveradalir an excellent outdoor classroom for understanding volcanic processes. The area has been protected since 2017 as part of Kerlingarfjöll Nature Reserve.

Accessing Hveradalir requires traveling on mountain roads (F-roads) that are only open during summer months, typically from late June through early September. The journey from the Ring Road takes approximately 2-3 hours via F35 (Kjölur route). A mountain lodge at Kerlingarfjöll provides accommodation and serves as the base for exploring Hveradalir. Several hiking trails of varying difficulty radiate from the lodge, with the walk to Hveradalir taking about 45 minutes each way. The area offers exceptional opportunities for photography, particularly during morning hours when steam plumes catch the low Arctic sun. Visitors should bring warm, waterproof clothing as weather can change rapidly in the highlands.
